content.description:
A nice pitch that reaches a big ledge cutting across the whole face that is useful in descent of many longer routes on the crag. It's located on the left end of the big slabby and attractive west face, just before some harsh looking roofs. The accompanying photo will help identify the start.

Climb cracks and corners to some easier ground. Move left and up towards a shallow dihedral, then ascend this feature to the big ledge.   Alot of fun.
content.protection: A standard granite free rack is sufficient. Small stoppers are handy on SCB. The pro is good.
content.location:
Check out the Description portion for info on Location.

Once on the ledge, follow it up and right the far end, about a rope length, where a super block is well slung for a rap to the ground. It can be done in two raps with a single line -- there's an established anchor part way down -- or make it to the ground with two ropes.

Pick another route....

content.description: Fun route on beautiful Wyoming granite! Starts with a short and steep splitter hand crack, then a slab traverse to the right, protected by a single bolt, over to a flake. Follow the flake up to a nice belay ledge with 2 bolted anchors. From the anchors, keep following the flake up through a small roof, which I would say is the crux. After the roof, the flake goes for some more before ending in another slab section, with protection right where you need it, and then up some steeper, but easier climbing to a huge ledge. There is a 2 bolt anchor at this ledge, and you can double rope rap down, or single rope rap to previous anchors, or walk off following the ledge to climbers left, or keep going up one of the routes up to the top. Route can be done in one pitch with good rope management.
content.protection: A single rack to 3" and a set of stoppers will suffice. Both anchors have rap rings. Only bolt is the one on the slab traverse section.
content.location: Route is the next one to the right (East) of the start for Photo Finish and Black Book. Look for the obvious crack going up into a slab.
